channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Saks Gets $600 Million Lifeline as Creditors Turn on One Another
item.description: Saks Global Enterprises has reached a $600 million debt deal with a number of its existing investors that would force some creditors to accept losses and push them back in the repayment priority line.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon, Reshmi Basu

media:content.media:description: A shopper carries a Saks Fifth Avenue.

item.title: Grifols Paid Family-Linked Firm More for Plasma
item.description: Spanish drugmaker Grifols SA paid a higher price to buy blood plasma from an entity linked to its controlling family than from third-party suppliers, according to a regulator’s findings submitted in a court case.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga, Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian passes the Grifols SA headquarters in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Grifols slumped to the lowest in more than a decade after Moody’s Investors Service placed the Spanish blood plasma company’s rating on review for downgrade and short seller Gotham City Research raised new questions on its accounting methods.

item.title: Lula to Go to Top Court to Challenge Overturn of Tax Decree
item.description: President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s administration will appeal to Brazil’s Supreme Court to try to preserve a tax decree that Congress overturned this week, according to two government officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

item.title: Trump Mobile Pulls ‘Made in USA’ Claim
item.description: The Trump Mobile, a phone company, has removed language from its website claiming that its phone is made in the USA. Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow gives an update on the company’s claim and what could be behind it.

item.title: S&P 500 Hits Session High on Trump’s Trade Remarks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s hopes that its worst fears about the impacts of tariffs on the economy may not come to fruition drove stocks toward all-time highs, with bets growing that the US and its top trade partners are moving closer to clinching deals. A rally in bonds stalled. Oil erased gains.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly says tariffs may not lead to a large or sustained inflation surge. She also says her view remains that there could be an interest rate cut in the fall. Daly says monetary policy is in a "good place." She speaks on "Bloomberg Surveillance."

item.title: Oil Steadies at End of Turbulent Week as Focus Shifts to Tariffs
item.description: Oil swung as traders weighed reports that OPEC+ may extend its run of super-sized production increases against conflicting comments on the status of nuclear talks between the US.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Julia Fanzeres

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks in Richmond, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: How Investing in Tehran Is Like Bitcoin in 2010
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: A demonstrator waves an Iranian flag during a protest against war with Iran outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, June 22, 2025. The US carried out airstrikes on three nuclear sites in Iran overnight, directly entering Israel's war with Tehran despite President Donald Trump's longtime promises to avoid new foreign conflicts. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: Union Authorizes Strike at Tyson Foods’ Beef Plant in Texas
item.description: Workers at Tyson Foods Inc.’s beef plant in Amarillo, Texas, have agreed to a strike as they fight for higher wages and accuse the company of unfair labor practices.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

item.title: Traders Ignoring ‘Warning Flags’ in S&P Rally, Citi Wealth CIO Fears
item.description: With US stocks trading at all-time highs despite a wealth of risks from President Donald Trump’s looming tariff deadline, war in the Middle East and rising economic uncertainty, some big-time money managers are growing concerned about where the market stands.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: European Gas Posts Biggest Weekly Drop in Two Years as Risks Ebb
item.description: European natural gas prices posted their biggest weekly retreat in almost two years after supply fears linked to tensions in the Middle East eased.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya

item.title: Gold Heads for Weekly Loss as Trade Talks Help Ease Haven Demand
item.description: Gold headed for its second straight weekly loss as progress on global trade talks and rising US consumer sentiment helped reduce the appeal for the safe-haven asset.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Jack Ryan, Yihui Xie

item.title: Why Rare Earths Are China’s Trump Card in Trade War With US
item.description: Rare earths are among the most critical raw materials on the planet, deeply embedded in the technologies that underpin modern life. Yet few people had even heard of them until the eruption of the US-China trade war thrust them into the limelight.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: Annealed neodymium iron boron magnets sit in a barrel prior to being crushed into powder.

item.title: OPEC+ Is Set to Weigh Another Super-Sized Oil Output Boost
item.description: OPEC+ is set to consider extending its run of super-sized production increases at a meeting next month, as group leader Saudi Arabia leads a push to recoup market share.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Grant Smith, Fiona MacDonald

item.title: FDIC Backs Plan on Key Bank Capital Rule Affecting Treasuries
item.description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. advanced regulators’ plan to ease a key capital rule that big banks have said limits their ability to act as intermediaries in the $29 trillion Treasuries market.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: The FDIC headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: California Democrats Push Reforms to Prevent Refinery Shutdowns
item.description: A group of California Democrats is looking to ease the state’s gasoline standards and streamline permitting for refineries in a bid to prevent more fuelmakers from shutting down and raising costs for the state’s drivers.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Risser

item.title: Meat Giant JBS Says Investor Demand for Its Bonds Undercuts ESG Concerns
item.description: JBS NV’s New York listing was met with fierce opposition from activist groups and politicians over the meat producer’s ESG record. Many investors, however, seem willing to look the other way.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: JBS NV signage at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. JBS NV shares started trading in New York on June 13, giving the world's largest meat producer a market value of about $15 billion as it culminated a years-long effort to reach a broader pool of investors.

item.title: Mercedes Helps to Power "F1: The Movie"
item.description: Mercedes was one of the driving forces behind "F1: The Movie." Melody Lee, Mercedes-Benz USA Chief Marketing Officer, joined "Bloomberg Open Interest" with Matt Miller and Sonali Basak ahead of the movie's release. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/27/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Euro Poised for Best Run Since 2017 as Dollar’s Slump Picks Up
item.description: The euro is set for its longest stretch of monthly gains in eight years, boosted by rising confidence in Europe’s economic prospects and a hunt for alternatives to the slumping dollar.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis, Anya Andrianova, Ruth Carson

item.title: Zambia Takes Steps to Avoid Landing on US Travel Ban List
item.description: Zambia says it has made progress in addressing several concerns raised by the US government, as it seeks to avoid being placed on an expanded travel ban list.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Lusaka, Zambia, on Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. For over a decade, China poured more than $120 billion of government-backed loans through its Belt and Road Initiative to build hydropower plants, roads and rail lines across the continent — as well as unparalleled influence.

item.title: Romanian Leader Pledges More Budget Measures to Curb Deficit
item.description: Romania’s premier outlined fresh measures to cut the ballooning budget deficit as the new government seeks to safeguard the country’s investment-grade rating and ease investor concern.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Designated Prime Minister Ilie Bolojan gives a joint press statement with the Romanian President at Cotroceni Palace, the Romanian Presidency's headquarters, in Bucharest June 20, 2025.

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds FCC Telecom Subsidy Fund
item.description: The US Supreme Court upheld, in a 6-3 vote, the $8.6 billion Universal Service Fund, the annual slate of subsidies that helps cover the cost of telecom services for low-income people, rural residents, schools and libraries. Tyler Kendall reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Bloomberg Invest Hong Kong Highlights
item.description: Held in Hong Kong, Bloomberg Invest convenes allocators, dealmakers, and investors from across Asia. Powered by one of the world's largest newsrooms, the 2025 event highlighted the most influential voices discussing the impact of tariffs on markets, opportunities across private assets, and tensions over US-China tech. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: EU, US Believe They’ll Reach Trade Pact by July Deadline
item.description: The EU and the US believe they can reach a trade agreement before a July 9 deadline, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products and the EU plans to impose its own countermeasures. Tyler Kendall reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: Citi’s Kate Moore Sees Tech Stocks Leading Markets in 2H
item.description: “We need to be balanced about what might happen in the second half of this year,” Citi Wealth Chief Investment Officer Kate Moore says. Speaking on “Bloomberg Open Interest,” Moore says she expects the macro and policy headwinds to be in place over the next few quarters and sees tech stocks leading the way going into 2026.

item.title: Life Insurers Boost Private Debt Investments In Yield Grab
item.description: Global life insurance companies are facing competitive pressure to keep boosting their allocations to private credit to generate higher profit, even as risk in the debt shows signs of rising.
item.dc:creator: Ethan M Steinberg

item.title: Fed-Driven Bond Rally Stalls With Yields Lowest Since May
item.description: Treasuries fell Friday but remained on course for a third straight weekly gain, with benchmark yields near the lowest levels since early May.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: The United States Department of the Treasury building in Washington DC.

item.title: Adler Weighs Sale of Prized €3.5 Billion Berlin Rental Portfolio
item.description: Adler Group SA is weighing the sale of its prized portfolio of Berlin apartments, a deal that would mark a landmark step in the slow unraveling of the scandal-hit German landlord.
item.dc:creator: Arno Schuetze, Libby Cherry

media:content.media:description: The Adler Group SA Uberlin luxury apartment construction site in Berlin, Germany, on Tuesday, Nov. 2, 2021. A major landlord in Germany, Adler has aggressively sold assets to help prop up its balance sheet, putting about 40% of the company’s portfolio on the block.

item.title: Boeing Wins Buy Rating as Redburn Sees ‘Healthier’ Company
item.description: Shares of Boeing Co. are set to make gains as the company speeds up production of commercial aircraft and takes steps to move on from a series of crises in recent years, according to Rothschild & Co. Redburn.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: Boeing Co.’s manufacturing facility in Renton, Washington.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Floating Solar Project Seeks $350 Million in Financing
item.description: Zimbabwe’s major power users are seeking as much as $350 million for an ambitious floating solar plant and have secured $4.4 million from the African Export-Import Bank for a feasibility study.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika
